main event: In Fort Worth, Texas, on 13th September 1952, a stationary whitish, round, and cigar-shaped object was observed in the sky for approximately 5 minutes before moving off rapidly at an estimated 7 to 10 miles altitude. No sound, trail, or exhaust was noticed during the observation.
interesting points: The object was observed to be highly stationary for 5 minutes before moving off rapidly, indicating unusual behavior.
The witness, a student from Fort Worth, alleged familiarity with all types of US aircraft, suggesting the ability to distinguish conventional aircraft from the observed object.
No unusual aircraft flights were reported by any military agency during the sighting period, raising questions about the nature of the observed object.
A radio sonde balloon was released around the sighting period, providing additional atmospheric data for analysis.
The sighting was reported by a credible witness, Captain Edward A. Payman of the USAF, who held the position of Operational Intelligence Officer at the time.
sighted object: stationary whitish, round, and cigar-shaped object in the sky
witnesses: Captain Edward A. Payman, a credible witness who was an Operational Intelligence Officer at the time
photographs: no photographs available in the report
